title: Kuhnemann debuts as Australia bowl first in Russell's farewell match

Current RR: 8.25

 • Last 5 ov (RR): 54/3 (10.80)

Live Forecast:WI 169

Report

West Indies remained unchanged while Australia also had Tim David back in the side

Toss Australia opt to bowl vs West Indies

Jake Fraser-McGurk and Sean Abbott were dropped while Matthew Kuhnemann makes his T20I debut and Tim David returns for Australia as they opt to bowl first against an unchanged West Indies line-up in Andre Russell's final international match at Sabina Park.

Both Fraser-McGurk and Abbott, though, could play again during the series as Australia are likely to continue to rotate their squad throughout.

Kuhnemann comes in as a second specialist spinner for his T20I debut in place of Abbott. He has previously played five Tests and four ODIs for Australia. David returns in place of Fraser-McGurk as Australia reshuffle the top order. Josh Inglis has been moved up to open alongside Mitchell Marsh while Cameron Green has moved to No. 3 and Glenn Maxwell returns to No. 4.

David will bat at No. 5, and game one's hero Mitchell Owen remains at No. 6, with Cooper Connolly also retaining his place, giving Marsh four spin-bowling options apart from the pace of Nathan Ellis, Ben Dwarshuis and Owen.

West Indies have kept faith with the same XI they fielded on Sunday, and will hope to send Russell out on a high and level the series 1-1 before heading to St Kitts for the final three T20Is.

Evin Lewis remains unavailable due to injury, meaning Brandon King, Shai Hope and Roston Chase will remain as the top three following their success with the bat in game one.

Australia: 1 Mitchell Marsh (capt), 2 Josh Inglis (wk), 3 Cameron Green, 4 Glenn Maxwell, 5 Tim David, 6 Mitchell Owen, 7 Cooper Connolly, 8 Ben Dwarshius, 9 Nathan Ellis, 10 Matthew Kuhnemann, 11 Adam Zampa

West Indies: 1 Brandon King, 2 Shai Hope (capt), 3 Roston Chase, 4 Shimron Hetmyer, 5 Rovman Powell, 6 Sherfane Rutherford, 7 Andre Russell, 8 Jason Holder, 9 Gudakesh Motie, 10 Akeal Hosein, 11 Alzarri Joseph

Alex Malcolm is an associate editor at ESPNcricinfo
